definition: to touch/to come in contact with/to feel/to be affected by/to catch fire/to burn/(coll.) to fall asleep/(after a verb) hitting the mark/succeeding in
aspect particle indicating action in progress

the five Liang of the Sixteen Kingdoms, namely: Former Liang 前涼|前凉 (314-376), Later Liang 後涼|后凉 (386-403), Northern Liang 北涼|北凉 (398-439), Southern Liang 南涼|南凉 (397-414), Western Liang 西涼|西凉 (400-421)

sentences.english: You wouldn't have caught cold if you had put on more clothes.
sentences.chinese: 多穿点衣服体你就不会着凉了。

sentences.english: The giantess stands on her tiny island.
sentences.chinese: 别站在风口上，小心着凉。

sentences.english: How did she ever catch cold in such warm weather?
sentences.chinese: 这样温暖的天气，她怎么会着凉的呢？

sentences.english: You Should Feed a Cold and Starve a Fever.
So that he could catch cold and become a little hoarse.
sentences.chinese: 这样他就可以着凉，嗓子就可以有些嘶哑。

sentences.english: If you don't wear a sweater, you will get cold.
sentences.chinese: 要是不穿毛线衣，你会着凉的。

sentences.english: Put on your overcoat, or you will catch cold.
sentences.chinese: 穿上你的外套，否则你会着凉的。

sentences.english: He suffers from a bad cold.
Chihuahuas have kind of a thin coat, so they get cold easily.
sentences.chinese: 吉娃娃只有薄薄的外衣，所以他们很容易着凉。

sentences.english: I quickly sluiced my face with cold water.
sentences.chinese: 我撩着凉水洗了一把脸。

sentences.english: If he had put on more clothes, he wouldn't have caught cold.
sentences.chinese: 他要是多穿点衣服，也不至于着凉。

sentences.english: If you sleep between damp sheets, you will probably catch cold.
sentences.chinese: 如果你睡在潮湿的被单里，就可能会着凉。

sentences.english: Cover yourself with a blanket lest you should catch a cold.
You'll avoid getting chilled by the wind after you've been sweating.
sentences.chinese: 你能避免在出汗后因风着凉。

sentences.english: Grandpa is afraid of trees catch cold snow, specially gave it a white coat.
sentences.chinese: 雪爷爷害怕大树着凉，特地送给它一件雪白的大衣。

definition: to catch cold/(common) cold/CL:場|场[chang2],次[ci4]/(coll.) to be interested in (often used in the negative)/(Tw) to detest/can't stand
to blow cold/damping expectations by discouraging or realistic words
to get wet in the rain
to have a high temperature (from illness)/to have a fever
